The [national](/wiki/National_flag "National flag") **flag
of[Ghana](/wiki/Ghana "Ghana")** was designed and adopted in 1957 and was
flown until 1962, and then reinstated in 1966. It consists of the [Pan-African
colours](/wiki/Pan-African_colours "Pan-African colours") of red, yellow, and
green, in horizontal stripes, with [a black five-pointed
star](/wiki/Black_star_of_Africa "Black star of Africa") in the centre of the
gold stripe. The Ghanaian flag was the second [African](/wiki/Africa "Africa")
flag after the [flag of the Ethiopian Empire](/wiki/Flag_of_Ethiopia#Colours
"Flag of Ethiopia") to feature these colours. The flag's design influenced
that of the [flag of Guinea-Bissau](/wiki/Flag_of_Guinea-Bissau "Flag of
Guinea-Bissau") (1973). It was designed by [Theodosia
Okoh](/wiki/Theodosia_Okoh "Theodosia Okoh").

The red represents the blood of those who died in the country's struggle for
independence from the Great Britain, the gold represents the mineral wealth of
the country, the green symbolises the country's rich forests and natural
wealth, and the black star is the symbol of African emancipation.[1] The black
star was adopted from the flag of the [Black Star Line](/wiki/Black_Star_Line
"Black Star Line"), a shipping line incorporated by [Marcus
Garvey](/wiki/Marcus_Garvey "Marcus Garvey") that operated from 1919 to
1922.[2] It is where the [Ghana national football
team](/wiki/Ghana_national_football_team "Ghana national football team") draw
their nickname, the _Black Stars_ , from.

## National
ensign[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Flag_of_Ghana&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: National ensign")]

Under terms of section 183 of Ghana's Merchant Shipping Act of 1963, the
[civil ensign](/wiki/Civil_ensign "Civil ensign") is a [red
flag](/wiki/Red_Ensign "Red Ensign") with the national flag in a
black-[fimbriated](/wiki/Fimbriation "Fimbriation")
[canton](/wiki/Flag_terminology "Flag terminology"). In 2003, a new merchant
shipping act was enacted, however, and this simply provides that "the National
Flag of Ghana" is the proper national colours for Ghanaian ships. No mention
is made of other flags or other possible flags.

The [naval ensign](/wiki/Naval_ensign "Naval ensign") is a red [St. George
cross](/wiki/St._George%27s_Cross "St. George's Cross") on [white
flag](/wiki/White_flag "White flag"), with the national flag in canton.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Civil_Air_Ensign_of_Ghana.svg/180px-

The Ghanaian civil air ensign  
  
The [Ghana Air Force](/wiki/Ghana_Air_Force "Ghana Air Force") has its own
ensign which incorporates the flag of Ghana. Civil aviation in Ghana is
represented by the national civil air ensign. It is a standard light blue
field with the Ghanaian flag in the canton. It is charged in the fly with
either a red, yellow and green roundel (in the case of the military ensign) or
black five-pointed star (in the case of the civil ensign). they have both been
used since independence, and the subsequent founding of the Ghana Air Force in
1959.

"Gold \(color\)") rim.  
  
The Ghanaian government flag, adopted in 1957, was flown until 1962.
Similarly, when the country formed the [Union of African
States](/wiki/Union_of_African_States "Union of African States"), the flag of
the Union was modelled on Bolivia's flag, but with two black stars,
representing the nations. In May 1959, a third star was added.

In 1962, prior to the dissolution of the Union the following year, Ghana
adopted a variant of the 1957 tricolour with white in the place of yellow,
after the colours of [Kwame Nkrumah](/wiki/Kwame_Nkrumah "Kwame Nkrumah")'s
ruling [Convention People's Party](/wiki/Convention_People%27s_Party
"Convention People's Party"), and similar to the [flag of
Hungary](/wiki/Flag_of_Hungary "Flag of Hungary"). The original 1957 flag was
reinstated in 1966 following Nkrumah's overthrow in [a _coup d
'état_](/wiki/National_Liberation_Council "National Liberation Council").

qa.question: what does the star on the ghana flag mean
qa.answer: ['adopted from the flag of the Black Star Line, a shipping line incorporated by Marcus Garvey that operated from 1919 to 1922']
